pros: Great department and fantastic students/colleagues. I loved every second here. Culture was great, campus is very nice, colleagues are kind and helpful. At the adjunct level, I felt no negativity.
cons: Adjunct pay is pitiful across the nation. Here, it was right in the middle on the pay scale per class. Benefits were fine. Wasn't confident I could have moved up without going back to grad school and getting an even more advanced degree.

pros: good vibes and chill campus

review_title: Definitely a step In the right direction
job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Huntsville, TX
pros: If you’re seeking a professional job while undergrad this is definitely a job for you. Understand that because it is career services and you are setting an example you are held to a higher standard than other jobs on campus. Super friendly environment and definitely had a lot of learning experiences. The job is a never ending learning experience as you continue you will get more out of it. Don’t be afraid of change and always ask questions.
cons: Leadership sometimes forgets we are undergraduate students and makes you prioritize work over school. They do work with you, but sometimes it can be put on the back burner If you cannot give 20 hours a week like they want they will choose someone else to be a lead PCA over someone more qualified and experienced

review_title: Not bad for a student job.
pros: My office provided a lot of job security; I was able to work there until I graduated. All the staff in my office were very nice and caring, and treated me like an equal for the most part. Many opportunities for cross-training and the ability to take on new assignments. I received a six-month raise and ended up making $9.00/hr. There were many networking opportunities that happened simply from being on the job.
cons: There were many times when I didn't have anything to work on, despite spending hours doing training for special projects that didn't happen. Other employees were able to get new furniture at the drop of a hat, but I developed posture issues from having to hunch over a desk in an old chair. My office hired me to work opposite hours of an adult staffer, who made almost twice as much per hour to do the same job that I did. Keeping a professional dress code as a student was inconvenient, especially when it was 106 degrees outside. My supervisor would commonly forget that I had requested days off (months in advance), and sometimes I had to barter with other student workers to get them off.

pros: Great graduate staff. Very helpful as I worked through the program

review_title: Pure Definition of a Hostile Exclusive  Work Environment
pros: Typical State Job. Good benefits, steady pay. It takes an act of god to be fired.
cons:
It takes an act of god to be fired. Therefore, lots of people are coasting every day until retirement. There were so many people that worked there and no one knew what they did at all, including their managers. They hire people based on arbitrary goals that have nothing to do with skills, experience or even degrees. Nepotism is rampant. 
The Lowman Student Center became an increasingly hostile and juvenile place to work since I left.  I applied for any and all jobs I could find, over 100 jobs or more,  just so I could leave. People there are Toxic. Turnover rate has increased to a ridiculous degree. There's emotional manipulation, bullying and yelling is considered to be a leadership style for some odd reason. Public reception is considered more important than actually trying to admit or fix the real issues. Cussing, yelling, exclusion, bullying, humiliation, glory seeking people are in every corner.

pros: A great work environment with flexibility.
cons: No Cons. I enjoyed my time there.

pros: Good teaching experience for advanced opportunities.
cons: Low pay and often difficult work for the pay.

review_title: Great place to work as a student

cons: There is a lot of down time

cons: I was not receiving enough hours as a part-time worker.

job_title: Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros: It is inexpensive with relatively small class sizes
cons: Graduate student support is not great

review_title: I am a full time adjunct lecturer
pros: Good insurance and benefits and the admin of benefits are very professional.  Beautiful campus on small pretty town with easy access to big city amenities and international airport
cons: Rigid administration focused on budget and not quality of academic experience, too many "power couples" employed constrains growth of employees - some long time employees have major issues but are protected.  They damage the culture of the university.  Poor decision making when choosing deans and chairs has also limited the potential of the college. Poor pay and promotion not linked to performance but " who you drink with"

pros: For the most part, offices are great with working around class schedules. Have opportunity to get to know upper level university directors & such. I've always enjoyed the atmosphere of the office and the "family" culture that we have here at Sam. I've been a student worker for 4 years and have enjoyed every moment of it.
cons: Only being able to work a maximum of 20 hours a week and making minimum wage at nearly every on campus job. Depending on the position and the office, students deserve more pay for the things that they do. Unfortunately, thanks to government rules, we aren't allowed to work more hours and they won't give us more pay.

review_title: Great place to start a career in higher education
pros: Certain positions within the university allow individuals to work closely with the student body which is why I entered a career in higher education. The work/life balance is good and often times supervisors will allow employees to take coursework during the lunch hour if they are completing a bachelors degree or seeking a graduate level degree. On the whole, the staff is friendly. The university has implemented a new professional development series for faculty/staff which is a great opportunity to learn from internal and external professionals.
cons: As with most employment in education, the pay is low. Several nearby universities pay at a much higher rate. Unfortunately, the ability for advancement is low as well. With the area community and campus culture, many employees stay for the remainder of their career, resulting in low turnover and the inability for entry-level and mid-management to move up.

pros: Wonderful benefits, friendly culture over all, often flexible and understanding, good training and continuing education opportunities.  Overall this is a great place to work.
cons: Upward advancement is very limited, nepotism and the buddy system are rampant and often preclude meritorious hiring and promotion.  The top level management have no idea what goes on beneath them and frankly they don't seem to care as long as it does not rock whatever boat they are in.

pros: Relaxed environment & great benefits! Start out earning 1 vacation day and 1 sick day every month which vacation increases with more years of service, 100% paid full-time employee insurance health premiums and partially paid dependent health insurance premiums, flexible schedule, 2 weeks paid Christmas holidays, other normal paid holidays, free gym membership with 30 minutes paid to work out!  Currently, caring management & co-workers but this depends on which department you are in and can change as in any job.
cons: Policies and procedures change without notice.

pros: Medium size campus, tenure, people are nice to work with and flexible in scheduling, there's room for creativity. There's a chance to travel to conferences. Improving job skills is often funded and highly supported.
cons: Small and boring town. Though the school isn't religious, many of the workers are outspokenly so and can make a person uncomfortable. The open hours are ridiculous when there are few students who use the library so late or early. Tenure can be stressful to acheive and may be frustrating when you want to focus solely on your job but find yourself forced to publish or lose the job.

review_title: Good in knowledge, bad in pay, no raises, no benefits, bad manager!
job_title: Operations Student Assistant in Huntsville, TX
pros: Great place to get experience and learn new things, when you need experience as a student take the job here its worth it, but once you get the experience, start looking for another job. The environment is very relaxed.
cons: You don't get paid what your worth, if you can find another IT job that is willing to take you and pay more go with that instead. THE ENVIRONMENT IS TOO RELAXED!!! You learn new things then the boss never assigns new work...

pros: As a graduate assistant, I had a rewarding time learning and working at SHSU. It was an amazing experience, and one that I wish could have lasted longer. It was the first time I was able to experience managing groups of my peers in innovative ways through multiple methods.
cons: As with any graduate assistant position, the job only lasts as long as the degree program. While pay is not the best, the experience is more than worth the time.

review_title: Nice environment, Just wish the pay was better
pros: The pros are first of all the job security.  There are many employees in undergraduate admissions that have been here for 5 plus years and this is their second family.  We get good health insurance that is comparable to Blue Cross/Blue Shield.  Staff also gets free access to the school gym, concerts and games.
cons: Pay is low for many staff positions and it's very hard to secure a position within the university.  It took a month and a half after I applied for the position to be hired.

review_title: Only good if you're in the "club"
pros: You receive a paycheck on a regular basis.  Most employees are great to work with.
cons: Management is under qualified in most departments.  You only will promote if you are in the "club."  There are no raises, and no promotions.  Benefits are sub par and when you do try to use any, you are questioned about why.  There is no reason anyone should work for this University.  Save yourself the downtime in your career and apply somewhere else.

pros:
Free rent, which is nice if you get positioned in one of the nicer dorms. Unfortunately if you're a woman you'll probably get put in Estill, Belvin, Elliot, or the hill.

The job can be very fun at times depending on your working staff.

While you're "on duty" you can do your homework or invite friends over, basically whatever you want as long as its inside the dorm and you answer the phone if it rings.

The job itself really isn't difficult and you have you do something really bad to get fired, although they will constantly write you up but it doesn't really mean anything.
cons:
They give you a certain number of hours a week regardless of how many hours you work and the pay is minimum wage.

Alot of your experience has everything to do with what dorm placement you are in. If you get put in an all girl dorm you have to do more work, you have more days that you have to work since the workload is split up and there are less RAs in the girl dorms, you will have less weekends off, and get paid the same as everyone else. 

They always come up with new ideas about how to make the RAS work longer hours while getting paid the same. 

The interviews and training is super cheesy. They basically treat the Rookies like kindergarteners.

Did I mention that they have cameras in the dorms and they will use them to spy on you to make sure you're doing your job. It creates a pretty weird atmosphere knowing you're getting spyed on.

job_title: Lead Staff Member in Huntsville, TX
pros: Close to, if not on campus. Constantly hiring. Variety of minimum wage jobs. Flexible schedules.
cons: Very basic jobs. Limited career advancement. Payment is not equal to responsibility in certain positions. Communication between employer and employee not great.

pros: Administration and professors were very supportive, and willing to incorporate my ideas into their classes. As a collective, the TAs were able to set their own office hours, and the job itself taught me a great deal about teaching, maintaining records and organization, and people skills in dealing either with faculty or students.
cons: Depending on the professor you work for your work load will vary wildly. This is understandable however, and changes depending on which course you assist in, and how your professor likes to run their classes.

review_title: Wonderful learning experience working for a major university.
pros: The work hours were somewhat flexible. Great teamwork! Great experience of learning how a department/university runs, and working with students and all levels of administration.
cons: I was not aware when I took the job that I would not have the same time off as students for holidays (i.e. Spring Break I worked). Not having holidays off made it challenging to have down time from school. Was a graduate student when I had this job.

pros: A mission that is easy to support, generally flexible, congenial and supportive work environment, latitude to innovate and contribute.  The students keep the work fresh and the campus is beautiful.
cons: Lower pay than industry.  Overly bureaucratic business processes.  Poor performers rewarded with longevity.  Sometimes seems like the focus is too much on the money and not enough on the students.

job_title: Administrative Associate III in Huntsville, TX
pros: Excellent Health Benefits, 2 Weeks Off for Christmas/New Year's Holidays; Advancement Possibilities
cons: Not a good company to work for if you are pregnant or have small children due to the fact that you are expected to work around the clock (depending on the department that you work for). Also, there is definitely a bit of ageism towards younger employees no matter how qualified you are, how long you have worked there, or how many degrees you have.

pros: You can do homework while at work (sometimes), (most) professors care for you as an individual and for the success of you as a student/professional
cons: While it's nice to have a lot of time off, it's rather difficult because you do not get as many hours as you would other places. Sometimes it's tough, as well, having everything (school/work) be within the hours of 8-5. Along with that, sometimes you have to deal with crazy people (like normal jobs).

pros:
the university has great benefits. United Healthcare
endless employee training for those who want to get the best out of their employment at the university
extended holidays
cons: inadequate salary. the opportunity cost for great benefits, is a low salary. Working for the state means little pay

review_title: Good company, Impossible to get hired unless you know someone
pros: Great people, good pay, occasional opportunities to move up, experience here looks good on a resume, best jobs and pay in Huntsville, Good benefits for full-time employees.
cons: Few if any benefits for part-time and/or student employees, Odds of being asked to come in for an interview are extremely low, High number of competing applicants, Departments usually already know who they want to hire.

pros: Flexible schedules, work well with students and encourage you to peruse higher education. (Masters, Phd)
cons: Can get slow, have to find ways to keep busy. Low pay, limited hours so if you are looking to work weekends you should look elsewhere

review_title: My experience at SHSU has been wonderful.
pros: They are very understanding and friendly. Everyone is always willing to help out and they want you to do well and succeed.
cons: I am a student assistant and I don't really have any cons about working here. The only thing is that I work about 20 hours a week which is hard to balance school and work.

pros: Great environment to learn, will be given the opportunity to teach a class or two. Great and helpful faculties
cons: Managing and dividing time between school work and TA duties might be hard because of the intense course work, and its level of difficulty.

job_title: Technology Inventory Specialist II in Huntsville, TX
pros: Benefits are excellent and opportunities to learn are always available.
cons: Just as any with mot companies, office politics do happen and even those not wanting to participate can hardly avoid it.

job_title: Student Access Services in Midlothian, TX
pros: I absolutely loved the management. They were organized with their schedule making but very understanding of my busy schedule.
cons: The slow times that I worked in the library, they were filled with random menial tasks.

pros: As a student they work well with your school schedule, friendly supervisors, and decent wages for an on campus job.
cons: Too many bosses, I have 6 people above me and i'm not at the bottom of the totem pole. Sometimes the work is hectic, and other times it's extremely dull.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Huntsville, TX
pros: The College of CJ is one of the nation's best! I really enjoyed the experience while teaching various courses there.
cons: The town is a little bit small but it has nothing to do with the univeristy or administration of course. You can drive down to Woodlands or Houston for shopping and social activities.

pros: Friendly people, easy going atmosphere, not a hard job at all
cons: No air conditioner in the warehouse, a lot of change happening and reorganization with new upper management

review_title: Good for teaching bad for administration
pros: Students tend to be committed, good support for scholarship.
cons: Administration has no interest in faculty input.  Obsession with online, little interest in rigor in classroom.

review_title: Treating people and programs more equally
pros: friendly campus, accessibility of buildings, slow but decent growth
cons: administration does not respect/value female leadership and their abilities.

pros:
1. The administration is very supportive. 
2. The location is easily accessible to Houston, Dallas, or Austin.
3. Always looking for ways to improve their employees lives and benefits.
cons:
1. Huntsville is not a great city to live in.
2. Available parking is lacking.

pros: Generous paid time off and benefits package
cons: Bad management reduces the value of any benefits. Low salaries. Advancement opportunities for staff are practically non-existent.

pros: Easy work for the most part, never very demanding
cons: The scheduling is completely messed up. Half of the people here have no idea what they are doing. If they mess up they blame the workers below them.

pros: Great position to have while being a full-time student because there is time to work on your studies.
cons: Minimum wage is hard to get by on and the number of hours students are allowed to work during the week is limited to twenty.

pros: This is an awesome place to start to get experience in your field your always working on project and your also able to win awards and get your name out there .
cons: You work minimum wage. but you can get plenty of hours

review_title: Great place to work while doing your masters degree.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Huntsville, TX
pros: The departments work with you to make sure you are successful.
cons: You are in a small town, so if you're looking for a bit city feel you will be about an hour away of Downtown Houston.

pros: good environment, nice salary, good work experience, excellent management, friendly, overall excellent work experience, no strict schedules, can leave if having any important work, supervisors are very helpful,
cons: i don have any complaints bcoz I got everything working here

pros:
Great environment. 
Annual raises.
6 month raises possible.
Good benefits.
Training booklets are useful.
cons:

LOTS of training for Banner. Training sessions are usually people just reading their powerpoint slides to you.

pros: Best tutoring environment I've ever been apart of.

job_title: Teaching Assistant, Research Assistant in Huntsville, TX
pros: nice environment, nice payment, and your job also helps your own study (Criminal Justice College)
cons: depending on different professors, your workload may be different but the payment is same (Criminal Justice College)

pros: Great location and the people and extremely friendly. The weather is good. Great for a folk considering retirement.
cons: Living expenses quite high and pays little. Slight and less competitive scientific environment. Expensive flight tickets to get to mainland conferences.

pros: paid health insurance, time off accrued at decent rate, tuition at a very low cost for employees.
cons: IT management was horrible. The VP would absorb the university allotted bonuses into his and the AVP's salary. Client Services never got pay raises.

job_title: Marketing & Promotions Graduate Assistant in Huntsville, TX
pros: Flexible hours with ability to work with supervisor. Also, ability to utilize campus resources such as Rec Center and more for free.
cons: Camaraderie within departments were not always pleasant - ultimately making working tense and uncomfortable in some cases.

pros: Good opportunity for students to work and get to know more faculty members. They are flexible and understand students requirements.
cons: Can't really think of anything negative about this job.

review_title: helped out at the student health center
pros: worked week days, no weekends, friendly staff, and retively easy job

pros: Great job to have while working on your Master's, a lot of opportunity to travel.

pros: Very family friendly. Lots of options for professional development. Student focus is strong.

pros: Great benefits and wonderful people to work with and you make your own schedule
cons: Working hours can be long, and you cannot leave your area.

pros: Friendly, if you're a student it's easy to commute, schedule based around classes

review_title: Not the place to work and go to school

review_title: Sam Houston used to be a very good place to work. Executive Management has destroyed the work environment.
